title: Confusing error messages by using double variable name

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
### Code

```Rust
let number one = 1;
```


### Current output

```Shell
error: expected one of `:`, `;`, `=`, `@`, or `|`, found `one`
  --> src\main.rs:14:17
   |
14 |      let number one = 1;
   |                 ^^^ expected one of `:`, `;`, `=`, `@`, or `|`
```


### Desired output

```Shell
error: expected only one variable name, found `one`
  --> src\main.rs:14:17
   |
14 |      let number one = 1;
   |                 ^^^ delete `one`
```


### Rationale and extra context

_No response_

### Other cases

_No response_

### Anything else?

Its a simple error but for new programmers it will be very helpful to have a better error message. I think it will be easy to fix, because it can be checked if there is a space after the variable name and then more letters. If this is the case, then my error message can be output.
